  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.05290v4</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T11:08:14Z</updated>
    <published>2017-05-15T15:27:15Z</published>
    <title>Geometry of the moduli space of $n$-pointed K3 surfaces of genus 11</title>
    <summary>  We prove that the moduli space of polarized $K3$ surfaces of genus eleven
with $n$ marked points is unirational when $n\leq 6$ and uniruled when
$n\leq7$. As a consequence, we settle a long standing but not proved assertion
about the unirationality of $\cal{M}_{11,n}$ for $n\leq6$. We also prove that
the moduli space of polarized $K3$ surfaces of genus eleven with $9$ marked
points has non-negative Kodaira dimension.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ignacio Barros</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Final version, typos corrected and some proofs simplified. To appear
  in Bull. London Math. Soc</arxiv:comment>

    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.07370v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T09:18:40Z</updated>
    <published>2015-06-24T14:05:15Z</published>
    <title>Hochschild cohomology of torus-equivariant D-modules</title>
    <summary>  We discuss the Hochschild cohomology of the category of D-modules associated
to an algebraic stack. In particular we describe the Hochschild cohomology of
the category of torus-equivariant D-modules as the cohomology of a D-module on
the loop space of the quotient stack. Finally, we give an approach for
understanding the Hochschild cohomology of D-modules on general stacks via a
relative compactification of the diagonal. This work is motivated by a desire
to understand the support theory (in the sense of Benson-Iyengar-Krause) of
D-modules on stacks.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Clemens Koppensteiner</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Minor edits</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.07370v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1506.07370v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.08481v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T08:34:23Z</updated>
    <published>2018-04-23T14:54:11Z</published>
    <title>The Hilbert scheme of hyperelliptic Jacobians and moduli of Picard
  sheaves</title>
    <summary>  Let $C$ be a hyperelliptic curve embedded in its Jacobian $J$ via an
Abel-Jacobi map. We compute the scheme structure of the Hilbert scheme
component of $\textrm{Hilb}_J$ containing the Abel-Jacobi curve as a point. We
relate the result to the ramification (and to the fibres) of the Torelli
morphism $\mathcal M_g\rightarrow \mathcal A_g$ along the hyperelliptic locus.
As an application, we determine the scheme structure of the moduli space of
Picard sheaves (introduced by Mukai) on a hyperelliptic Jacobian.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Andrea T. Ricolfi</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Added application to Picard sheaves</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.08481v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1804.08481v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03451v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T08:20:01Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-10T08:20:01Z</published>
    <title>Explicit uniform estimate of arithmetic Hilbert-Samuel function of
  hypersurfaces</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we will give an upper bound and a lower bound of the
arithmetic Hilbert-Samuel function of projective hypersurfaces, which are
uniform and explicit. These two bounds have the optimal dominant terms. As an
application, we use the lower bound to get an estimate of the density of
rational points with small heights in a hypersurface.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Chunhui Liu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">45 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03451v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.05503v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T07:19:24Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-15T07:33:20Z</published>
    <title>Equivariant holomorphic anomaly equation</title>
    <summary>  In [16] the fundamental relationship between stable quotient invariants and
the B-model for local P2 in all genera was studied under some specialization of
equivariant variables. We generalize the argument of [16] to full equivariant
settings without the specialization. Our main results are the proof of
holomorphic anomaly equations for the equivariant Gromov-Witten theories of
local P2 and local P3. We also state the generalization to full equivariant
formal quintic theory of the result in [17].
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hyenho Lho</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.02777v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T06:37:03Z</updated>
    <published>2016-11-08T23:59:29Z</published>
    <title>Exotic t-structures and actions of quantum affine algebras</title>
    <summary>  We explain how quantum affine algebra actions can be used to systematically
construct "exotic" t-structures. The main idea, roughly speaking, is to take
advantage of the two different descriptions of quantum affine algebras, the
Drinfeld--Jimbo and the Kac--Moody realizations.
  Our main application is to obtain exotic t-structures on certain convolution
varieties defined using the Beilinson--Drinfeld and affine Grassmannians. These
varieties play an important role in the geometric Langlands program, knot
homology constructions, K-theoretic geometric Satake and the coherent Satake
category. As a special case we also recover the exotic t-structures of
Bezrukavnikov--Mirkovic on the (Grothendieck--)Springer resolution in type A.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Sabin Cautis</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Clemens Koppensteiner</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">41 pages</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.09799v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-10T02:42:58Z</updated>
    <published>2018-04-25T21:00:32Z</published>
    <title>Rational Homology Manifolds and Hypersurface Normalizations</title>
    <summary>  We prove a criterion for determining whether the normalization of a complex
analytic space on which the constant sheaf is perverse is a rational homology
manifold, using a perverse sheaf known as the multiple-point complex. This
perverse sheaf is naturally associated to any "parameterized space", and has
several interesting connections with the Milnor monodromy and mixed Hodge
Modules.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Brian Hepler</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.09799v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03366v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T22:42:20Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-09T22:42:20Z</published>
    <title>Polynomial-like elements in vector spaces with group actions</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we study polynomial-like elements in vector spaces equipped
with group actions. We first define these elements via iterated difference
operators. In the case of a full rank lattice acting on an Euclidean space,
these polynomial-like elements are exactly polynomials with periodic
coefficients, which are closely related to solutions of periodic differential
equations. Our main theorem confirms that if the space of polynomial-like
elements of degree zero is of finite dimension then for any $n \in
\mathbb{Z}_+$, the space consisting of all polynomial-like elements of degree
at most $n$ is also finite dimensional.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Minh Kha</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Vladimir Lin</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">To appear in Contemporary Mathematics</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03366v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01383v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T19:18:15Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-03T22:41:33Z</published>
    <title>Tropical Jucys Covers</title>
    <summary>  We study monotone and strictly monotone Hurwitz numbers from a bosonic Fock
space perspective. This yields to an interpretation in terms of tropical
geometry involving local multiplicities given by Gromov-Witten invariants.
Furthermore, this enables us to prove that a main result of
Cavalieri-Johnson-Markwig-Ranganathan is a actually a refinement of the
Gromov-Witten/Hurwitz correspondence by Okounkov-Pandharipande.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Marvin Anas Hahn</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Danilo Lewanski</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.08780v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T17:32:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-03-23T13:05:49Z</published>
    <title>Singular divisors and syzygies of polarized abelian threefolds</title>
    <summary>  For a polarized abelian threefold $(X,L)$ we provide a geometric criterion to
have simple syzygies such as satisfying the $N_p$-property and the vanishing of
Koszul cohomology groups $K_{p,1}$ for a given natural number $p\geq 0$. As in
previous work of the author with K\"uronya, we use the reduction method of
Lazarsfeld-Pareschi-Popa together with the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies.
This is enhanced by employing inversion of adjunction techniques coming from
both birational geometry and work on Fujita's conjecture together with the idea
of differentiation of sections developed by Ein-Lazarsfeld-Nakamye. As a
by-product, for an ample class with high self-intersection we construct
effective divisors on $X$ whose singularities are all concentrated on an
abelian subvariety. This can be thought as the dual picture of the classical
problem about singularities of theta divisors pioneered by Ein-Lazarsfeld and
Hacon.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Victor Lozovanu</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03245v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T17:28:57Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-09T17:28:57Z</published>
    <title>Refined $\mathrm{SU}(3)$ Vafa-Witten invariants and modularity</title>
    <summary>  We conjecture a formula for the refined $\mathrm{SU}(3)$ Vafa-Witten
invariants of any smooth surface $S$ satisfying $H_1(S,\mathbb{Z}) = 0$ and
$p_g(S)&gt;0$. The unrefined formula corrects a proposal by Labastida-Lozano and
involves unexpected algebraic expressions in modular functions. We prove that
our formula satisfies a refined $S$-duality modularity transformation.
  We provide evidence for our formula by calculating virtual $\chi_y$-genera of
moduli spaces of rank 3 stable sheaves on $S$ in examples using Mochizuki's
formula. Further evidence is based on the recent definition of refined
$\mathrm{SU}(r)$ Vafa-Witten invariants by Maulik-Thomas and subsequent
calculations on nested Hilbert schemes by Thomas (rank 2) and Laarakker (rank
3).
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Lothar Göttsche</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Martijn Kool</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">39 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03245v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.03245v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00028v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T16:10:42Z</updated>
    <published>2017-12-29T20:03:29Z</published>
    <title>Smooth quotients of abelian varieties by finite groups</title>
    <summary>  We give a complete classification of smooth quotients of abelian varieties by
finite groups. In the particular case where the action of the group $G$ on the
tangent space at the origin of the abelian variety $A$ is irreducible, we prove
that $A$ is isomorphic to the self-product of an elliptic curve and $A/G\simeq
\mathbb P^n$. In the general case, assuming $\dim(A^G)=0$, we prove that $A/G$
is isomorphic to a direct product of projective spaces.
  As an application, we give a complete classification of smooth quotients of
Jacobian varieties of curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Robert Auffarth</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Giancarlo Lucchini Arteche</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">28 pages. Comments are welcome! :)</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.00010v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T14:25:01Z</updated>
    <published>2018-06-29T18:00:05Z</published>
    <title>Global dimension function, Gepner equations and $\mathbb{X}$-stability
  conditions</title>
    <summary>  We study the global dimension function
$\operatorname{gl.dim}\colon\mathbb{C}\backslash\operatorname{Stab}\mathcal{D}/\operatorname{Aut}\to\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$
on the quotient space of Bridgeland's stability conditions on a triangulated
category $\mathcal{D}$ and Toda's Gepner equation $\Phi(\sigma)=s\cdot\sigma$
for some $\sigma\in\operatorname{Stab}\mathcal{D}$ and
$(\Phi,s)\in\operatorname{Aut}\mathcal{D}\times\mathbb{C}$. We show that
Kajiura-Saito-Takahashi's solution $\sigma_G$ of
$\tau(\sigma)=(-2/h)\cdot\sigma$, for the category of graded matrix
factorization $\mathcal{D}_\infty(Q)=\mathcal{D}^b(\mathbf{k}Q)$ for a Dynkin
quiver $Q$, gives the unique minimal value $1-2/h$ of $\operatorname{gl.dim}$.
Here $\tau$ is the Auslander-Reiten functor and $h$ is the Coxeter number.
  Moreover, we show that, for each Lagrangian immersion
$\mathcal{L}\colon\mathcal{D}_\infty(Q)\to\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$, the
Gepner point $\sigma_G$ in $\operatorname{Stab}\mathcal{D}_\infty(Q)$ induces a
solution $\sigma_{G,s}^\mathcal{L}$ of
$\tau_\mathbb{X}^\mathcal{L}(\sigma)=(-2/h)\cdot\sigma$ in Ikeda-Qiu's
$s$-fiber $\operatorname{\mathbb{X}Stab}_s\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$ of
$\mathbb{X}$-stability condition on the Calabi-Yau-$\mathbb{X}$ category
$\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$, provided $\operatorname{Re}(s)\ge2-2/h$. Here
$\operatorname{\mathbb{X}Stab}_s\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$ is defined by
another Gepner equation $\mathbb{X}(\sigma)=s\cdot\sigma$ and
$\tau_\mathbb{X}^\mathcal{L}=[\mathbb{X}-2]\circ \zeta_Q^\mathcal{L}$, where
$\zeta_Q^\mathcal{L}$ is a root of the generator of the center of the spherical
twist group $\operatorname{ST}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Yu Qiu</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.00010v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.00010v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.RT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.RT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.00469v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T14:12:46Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-02T05:30:32Z</published>
    <title>$\mathbb{X}$-stability conditions on Calabi-Yau-$\mathbb{X}$ categories
  and twisted periods</title>
    <summary>  We introduce $\mathbb{X}$-stability conditions $(\sigma,s)$ on
Calabi-Yau-$\mathbb{X}$ categories $\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$, where $\sigma$ is
a stability condition on $\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$ and $s$ a complex number.
Sufficient and necessary conditions are given, for a stability condition on an
$\mathbb{X}$-heart $\mathcal{D}_\infty$ of $\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$ to induce
$\mathbb{X}$-stability conditions on $\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$. As a
consequence, we show that the space
$\operatorname{QStab}\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$ of $q$-stability conditions
(induced $\mathbb{X}$-stability conditions) is a complex manifold, whose fibers
(fixing $s$) give usual type of spaces of stability conditions. Our motivating
examples for $\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}$ are coming from Calabi-Yau-$\mathbb{X}$
completions of dg algebras.
  A geometric application is that, for type $A$ quiver $Q$, the corresponding
space $\operatorname{\mathbb{X}Stab}^\circ_s\mathcal{D}_\mathbb{X}(Q)$ of
$q$-stability conditions admits almost Frobenius structure while the central
charge $Z_s$ corresponds to the twisted period $P_\nu$, for $\nu=(s-2)/2$,
where $s\in\mathbb{C}$ with $\operatorname{Re}(s)\ge2$. A categorical
application is that we realize perfect derived categories as
cluster(-$\mathbb{X}$) categories for acyclic quiver $Q$.
  In the sequel, we construct quivers with superpotential from flat surfaces
with the corresponding Calabi-Yau-$\mathbb{X}$ categories and realize
$q$-stability conditions as $q$-quadratic differentials.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Akishi Ikeda</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Yu Qiu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">A preliminary version, 39 pages, 2 figures. Comments are welcome</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1712.04836v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T10:20:16Z</updated>
    <published>2017-12-13T16:07:20Z</published>
    <title>Equivariant mirror symmetry for the weighted projective line</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we establish equivariant mirror symmetry for the weighted
projective line. This extends the results by B. Fang, C.C. Liu and Z. Zong,
where the projective line was considered [{\it Geometry \&amp; Topology}
24:2049-2092, 2017]. More precisely, we prove the equivalence of the
$R$-matrices for A-model and B-model at large radius limit, and establish
isomorphism for $R$-matrices for general radius. We further demonstrate that
the graph sum of higher genus cases are the same for both models, hence
establish equivariant mirror symmetry for the weighted projective line.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Dun Tang</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">15 pages, 2 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1712.04836v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03068v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T09:34:38Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-09T09:34:38Z</published>
    <title>Conjectures on the logarithmic derivatives of Artin L-functions II</title>
    <summary>  We formulate a general conjecture relating Chern classes of subbundles of
Gauss-Manin bundles in Arakelov geometry to logarithmic derivatives of Artin
L-functions of number fields. This conjecture may be viewed as a far-reaching
generalisation of the (Lerch-)Chowla-Selberg formula computing logarithms of
periods of elliptic curves in terms of special values of the $\Gamma$-function.
We prove several special cases of this conjecture in the situation where the
involved Artin characters are Dirichlet characters. This article contains the
computations promised in the article {\it Conjectures sur les d\'eriv\'ees
logarithmiques des fonctions L d'Artin aux entiers n\'egatifs}, where our
conjecture was announced. We also give a quick introduction to the
Grothendieck-Riemann-Roch theorem and to the geometric fixed point formula,
which form the geometric backbone of our conjecture.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Vincent Maillot</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Damian Rössler</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">54 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03068v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.03068v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03062v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T09:03:29Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-09T09:03:29Z</published>
    <title>The Straight Blow Up Section Family</title>
    <summary>  The straight blow up section family of a projection $X\times Y\to X$ along a
closed subscheme $Z$ of $X\times Y$ is an object that combines the universal
properties of the universal section family of $X\times Y\to X$ and of the blow
up of $X\times Y$ along $Z$. It is our attempt to characterise a unique
morphism between universal schemes of relatives clusters who emerged in the
author's previous work. To construct the straight blow up section family first
we develop a scheme theoretic version of the Chevalley's theorem for
projections and for the "codimension zero stratum".
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Laura Brustenga i Moncusí</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03062v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.03062v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03038v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T06:39:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-09T06:39:02Z</published>
    <title>On curves lying on a rational normal surface scroll</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we study the minimal free resolution of non-ACM divisors $X$
of a smooth rational normal surface scroll $S=S(a_1 ,a_2 ) \subset
\mathbb{P}^r$. Our main result shows that for $a_2 \geq 2a_1 -1$, there exists
a nice decomposition of the Betti table of $X$ as a sum of much simpler Betti
tables. As a by-product of our results, we obtain a complete description of the
graded Betti numbers of $X$ for the cases where $S=S(1,r-2)$ for some $r \geq
3$ and $S=S(2,r-3)$ for some $r \geq 6$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Wanseok Lee</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Euisung Park</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03038v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.03038v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="13D02, 14J26, 14N05" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.08647v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T04:23:22Z</updated>
    <published>2015-12-29T10:40:03Z</published>
    <title>Remarks on K3 surfaces with non-symplectic automorphisms of order 7</title>
    <summary>  In this note, we treat a pair of a K3 surface and a non-symplectic
automorphism of order 7m (m=1, 3 and 6) on it. We show that if the fixed locus
of a non-symplectic automorphism order 7 is "special" then the pair is unique
up to isomorphism. And we describe fixed loci of non-symplectic automorphisms
of order 21 and 42.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Shingo Taki</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">This paper has been withdrawn by the author because it turns out that
  the main result is not true</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.08647v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1512.08647v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02705v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-09T03:43:28Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T10:09:23Z</published>
    <title>Quillen type Bundles and Geometric quantization of vortex moduli spaces
  on Kahler surfaces</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we show that on projective manifolds, there are Quillen bundles
(in the sense of Bismut, Gillet Soule) which play the role of the geometric
quantum bundle, namely one defined for every aribitrary compact Kahler manifold
Z.We give several explicit examples of this phenomenon. For instance, moduli
space of the usual vortex equations on a projective Kahler 4 manifold is shown
to be projective using Quillen bundle construction under some mild conditions.
Next we generalize Manton's treatment of 5 vortex equations on a Riemann
surface namely we define on Kahler manifolds 4 manifolds. One of the cases was
well studied by Bradlow.We show when the Kahler mainfold is projective then 4
of the 5 cases the moduli is symplectic (Kahler in one case) and admit Quillen
bundles which are quantum line bundles that is curvature proportional to
symplectic (Kahler) form. They can be prequantized or quantized geometrically.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Rukmini Dey</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Saibal Ganguli</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">some typos corrected</arxiv:comment>

    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02955v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T22:22:57Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T22:22:57Z</published>
    <title>Fukaya category of Grassmannians: rectangles</title>
    <summary>  We show that the monotone Lagrangian torus fiber of the Gelfand-Cetlin
integrable system on the complex Grassmannian $\operatorname{Gr}(k,n)$ supports
generators for all maximum modulus summands in the spectral decomposition of
the Fukaya category over $\mathbb{C}$, generalizing the example of the Clifford
torus in projective space. We introduce an action of the dihedral group $D_n$
on the Landau-Ginzburg mirror proposed by Marsh-Rietsch that makes it
equivariant and use it to show that, given a lower modulus, the torus supports
nonzero objects in none or many summands of the Fukaya category with that
modulus. The alternative is controlled by the vanishing of rectangular Schur
polynomials at the $n$-th roots of unity, and for $n=p$ prime this suffices to
give a complete set of generators and prove homological mirror symmetry for
$\operatorname{Gr}(k,p)$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Marco Castronovo</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">35 pages, 5 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02955v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02955v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.SG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.SG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02936v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T20:56:09Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T20:56:09Z</published>
    <title>Arithmetic of hyperelliptic curves over local fields</title>
    <summary>  We study hyperelliptic curves y^2=f(x) over local fields of odd residue
characteristic. We introduce the notion of a "cluster picture" associated to
the curve, that describes the p-adic distances between the roots of f(x), and
show that this elementary combinatorial object encodes the curve's Galois
representation, conductor, whether the curve is semistable, and if so, the
special fibre of its minimal regular model, the discriminant of its minimal
Weierstrass equation and other invariants.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Tim Dokchitser</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Vladimir Dokchitser</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Céline Maistret</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02882v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T17:57:17Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T17:57:17Z</published>
    <title>The Double Complex of a Blow-up</title>
    <summary>  We compute the double complex of smooth complex-valued differential forms on
projective bundles over and blow-ups of compact complex manifolds up to a
suitable notion of quasi-isomorphism. This simultaneously yields formulas for
'all' cohomologies naturally associated with this complex (in particular,
de-Rham, Dolbeault, Bott-Chern and Aeppli).
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Jonas Stelzig</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02882v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.06126v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T17:32:29Z</updated>
    <published>2015-06-19T19:55:30Z</published>
    <title>Cusp and $b_1$ growth for ball quotients and maps onto $\mathbb{Z}$ with
  finitely generated kernel</title>
    <summary>  Let $M = \mathbb{B}^2 / \Gamma$ be a smooth ball quotient of finite volume
with first betti number $b_1(M)$ and let $\mathcal{E}(M) \ge 0$ be the number
of cusps (i.e., topological ends) of $M$. We study the growth rates that are
possible in towers of finite-sheeted coverings of $M$. In particular, $b_1$ and
$\mathcal{E}$ have little to do with one another, in contrast with the
well-understood cases of hyperbolic $2$- and $3$-manifolds. We also discuss
growth of $b_1$ for congruence arithmetic lattices acting on $\mathbb{B}^2$ and
$\mathbb{B}^3$. Along the way, we provide an explicit example of a lattice in
$\mathrm{PU}(2, 1)$ admitting a homomorphism onto $\mathbb{Z}$ with finitely
generated kernel. Moreover, we show that any cocompact arithmetic lattice
$\Gamma \subset \mathrm{PU}(n, 1)$ of simplest type contains a finite index
subgroup with this property.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Matthew Stover</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">v2 Added Theorem 3 and changed title to reflect new results; v3 To
  appear in Indiana Univ. Math. J</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.06126v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1506.06126v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02856v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T16:46:21Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T16:46:21Z</published>
    <title>On the Solvability of Viewing Graphs</title>
    <summary>  A set of fundamental matrices relating pairs of cameras in some configuration
can be represented as edges of a "viewing graph". Whether or not these
fundamental matrices are generically sufficient to recover the global camera
configuration depends on the structure of this graph. We study
characterizations of "solvable" viewing graphs and present several new results
that can be applied to determine which pairs of views may be used to recover
all camera parameters. We also discuss strategies for verifying the solvability
of a graph computationally.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Matthew Trager</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Brian Osserman</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jean Ponce</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">22 pages</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.03209v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T15:14:31Z</updated>
    <published>2017-11-08T23:34:53Z</published>
    <title>The wall-crossing formula and Lagrangian mutations</title>
    <summary>  We prove a general form of the wall-crossing formula which relates the disk
potentials of monotone Lagrangian submanifolds with their Floer-theoretic
behavior away from a Donaldson divisor. We define geometric operations called
mutations of Lagrangian tori in del Pezzo surfaces and in toric Fano varieties
of higher dimension, and study the corresponding wall-crossing formulas that
compute the disk potential of a mutated torus from that of the original one.
  In the case of del Pezzo surfaces, this justifies the connection between
Vianna's tori and the theory of mutations of Landau-Ginzburg seeds. In higher
dimension, this provides new Lagrangian tori in toric Fanos corresponding to
different chambers of the mirror variety, including ones which are
conjecturally separated by infinitely many walls from the chamber containing
the standard toric fibre.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>James Pascaleff</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Dmitry Tonkonog</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">54 pages, 8 figures; v2: minor improvements in discussion of

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02887v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T13:40:04Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T13:40:04Z</published>
    <title>On the torsion of rational elliptic curves over sextic fields</title>
    <summary>  Given an elliptic curve $E/\mathbb{Q}$ with torsion subgroup $G =
E(\mathbb{Q})_{\rm tors}$ we study what groups (up to isomorphism) can occur as
the torsion subgroup of $E$ base-extended to $K$, a degree 6 extension of
$\mathbb{Q}$. We also determine which groups $H = E(K)_{\rm tors}$ can occur
infinitely often and which ones occur for only finitely many curves. This
article is a first step towards a complete classification of torsion growth of
over sextic fields.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Harris B. Daniels</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Enrique González-Jiménez</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02887v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02760v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T13:21:21Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T13:21:21Z</published>
    <title>Irregular perverse sheaves</title>
    <summary>  We introduce irregular constructible sheaves, which are
$\mathbb{C}$-constructible with coefficients in a finite version of Novikov
ring $\Lambda$ and special gradings. We show that the category of
cohomologically irregular constructible complexes is equivalent to the the
bounded derived category of holonomic $\mathcal{D}$-modules by a modification
of D'Agnolo--Kashiwara's irregular Riemann--Hilbert correspondence. The
category of cohomologically irregular constructible complexes is equipped with
the irregular perverse t-structure, which is a straightforward generalization
of usual perverse t-structure and we see its heart is equivalent to the
category of holonomic $\mathcal{D}$-modules. We also develop the algebraic
version of the theory. Furthermore, we discuss the reason of the appearance of
Novikov ring by using a conjectural reformulation of Riemann--Hilbert
correspondence in terms of certain Fukaya category.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Tatsuki Kuwagaki</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">48 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02760v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02760v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02742v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T13:04:44Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T13:04:44Z</published>
    <title>Computing Unit Groups of Curves</title>
    <summary>  The group of units modulo constants of an affine variety over an
algebraically closed field is free abelian of finite rank. Computing this group
is difficult but of fundamental importance in tropical geometry, where it is
desirable to realize intrinsic tropicalizations. We present practical
algorithms for computing unit groups of smooth curves of low genus. Our
approach is rooted in divisor theory, based on interpolation in the case of
rational curves and on methods from algebraic number theory in the case of
elliptic curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Justin Chen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Sameera Vemulapalli</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Leon Zhang</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02742v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02742v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02735v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T12:13:00Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T12:13:00Z</published>
    <title>Donaldson-Thomas invariants of abelian threefolds and Bridgeland
  stability conditions</title>
    <summary>  We study the reduced Donaldson-Thomas theory of abelian threefolds using
Bridgeland stability conditions. The main result is the invariance of the
reduced Donaldson-Thomas invariants under all derived autoequivalences, up to
explicitly given wall-crossing terms. We also present a numerical criterion for
the absence of walls in terms of a discriminant function. For principally
polarized abelian threefolds of Picard rank one, the wall-crossing
contributions are discussed in detail. The discussion yield evidence for a
conjectural formula for curve counting invariants by Bryan, Pandharipande, Yin,
and the first author.
  For the proof we strengthen several known results on Bridgeland stability
conditions of abelian threefolds. We show that certain previously constructed
stability conditions satisfy the full support property. In particular, the
stability manifold is non-empty. We also prove the existence of a Gieseker
chamber and determine all wall-crossing contributions. A definition of reduced
generalized Donaldson-Thomas invariants for arbitrary Calabi-Yau threefolds
with abelian actions is given.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Georg Oberdieck</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Dulip Piyaratne</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Yukinobu Toda</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">58 pages, 1 figure</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02735v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02735v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.10104v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T11:09:56Z</updated>
    <published>2018-05-25T12:29:43Z</published>
    <title>Periods of $1$-motives</title>
    <summary>  We establish that all $\bar{\mathbf{Q}}$-linear relations between
one-dimensional periods (i.e., periods of algebraic curves, or equivalently
periods in cohomological degree $1$, or of Deligne $1$-motives over the field
of algebraic numbers) are induced by bilinearity and functoriality for
morphisms of $1$-motives. As a consequence we confirm Kontsevich's version of
the period conjecture for these periods. Note, however, that we have nothing to
say about algebraic relations.
  As a corollary, we characterise the one-dimensional periods that are
algebraic. For a fixed $1$-motive, we give an explicit formula for the
dimension of the space of its periods in the spirit of Baker's theorem and
indeed generalising it.
  The new version makes minor corrections and adds explicit period formulas and
transcendence results for elliptic curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Annette Huber</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Gisbert Wüstholz</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.10104v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.10104v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="11J81, 14F42, 14C15, 14C30" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02711v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-08T10:26:45Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-08T10:26:45Z</published>
    <title>MMP for co-rank one foliation on threefolds</title>
    <summary>  We prove existence of flips, special termination, the base point free theorem
and, in the case of log general type, the existence of minimal models for F-dlt
foliated log pairs of co-rank one on a projective threefold.
  As applications, we show the existence of F-dlt modifications and
F-terminalisations for foliated log pairs and we show that foliations with
canonical or F-dlt singularities admit non-dicritical singularities. Finally,
we show abundance in the case of numerically trivial foliated log pairs.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Paolo Cascini</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Calum Spicer</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">59 pages</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02549v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T20:50:36Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T20:50:36Z</published>
    <title>Extensions of mixed Hodge modules and Picard-Fuchs equations</title>
    <summary>  The normal function associated to algebraic cycles in higher Chow groups
defines a differential equation. This Picard-Fuchs equation defines an
extension of $D$-modules as well as an extension of local systems. In this
paper, we show that both extensions define the same extension of mixed Hodge
modules determined by the normal function.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Pedro Luis del Ángel R.</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>José Jaime Hernández C</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02549v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.00511v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T19:26:53Z</updated>
    <published>2017-01-02T20:08:54Z</published>
    <title>Frobenius-Seshadri constants and characterizations of projective space</title>
    <summary>  We introduce higher-order variants of the Frobenius-Seshadri constant due to
Musta\c{t}\u{a} and Schwede, which are defined for ample line bundles in
positive characteristic. These constants are used to show that Demailly's
criterion for separation of higher-order jets by adjoint bundles also holds in
positive characteristic. As an application, we give a characterization of
projective space using Seshadri constants in positive characteristic, which was
proved in characteristic zero by Bauer and Szemberg. We also discuss
connections with other characterizations of projective space.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Takumi Murayama</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:doi xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">10.4310/MRL.2018.v25.n3.a9</arxiv:doi>
    <link title="doi" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.4310/MRL.2018.v25.n3.a9" rel="related"/>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">19 pages. v2: Remark 3.3 added to discuss singularities, Propositions
  2.8 and 2.11 added, references added, other small changes. v3: Fixed diagram
  on p. 16, other small changes</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:journal_ref xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Math. Res. Lett. 25 (2018), no. 3, 905-936</arxiv:journal_ref>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04079v7</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T19:22:02Z</updated>
    <published>2016-02-12T15:16:04Z</published>
    <title>$J$-invariant of hermitian forms over quadratic extensions</title>
    <summary>  We develop the version of the $J$-invariant for hermitian forms over
quadratic extensions in a similar way Alexander Vishik did it for quadratic
forms. This discrete invariant contains informations about rationality of
algebraic cycles on the maximal unitary grassmannian associated with a hermitan
form over a quadratic extension. The computation of the canonical $2$-dimension
of this grassmannian in terms of the $J$-invariant is provided, as well as a
complete motivic decomposition.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Raphaël Fino</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04079v7" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04079v7" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.03217v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T15:43:57Z</updated>
    <published>2017-10-09T17:53:16Z</published>
    <title>W-algebras associated to surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We define an integral form of the deformed W-algebra of type gl_r, and
construct its action on the K-theory groups of moduli spaces of rank r stable
sheaves on a smooth projective surface S, under certain assumptions. Our
construction generalizes the action studied by Nakajima, Grojnowski and
Baranovsky in cohomology, although the appearance of deformed W-algebras by
generators and relations is a new feature. Physically, this action encodes the
AGT correspondence for 5d supersymmetric gauge theory on S x circle.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Andrei Neguţ</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">typos fixed, presentation style improved</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.03217v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1710.03217v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.QA" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14J60" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.00390v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T15:42:19Z</updated>
    <published>2017-11-01T15:24:16Z</published>
    <title>AGT relations for sheaves on surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We consider a natural generalization of the Carlsson-Okounkov Ext operator on
the K-theory groups of the moduli spaces of stable sheaves on a smooth
projective surface. We compute the commutation relations between the Ext
operator and the action of the deformed W-algebra on K-theory, which was
developed in [18]. The conclusion is that the Ext operator is closely related
with a vertex operator, thus giving a mathematical incarnation of the
Alday-Gaiotto-Tachikawa correspondence for a general algebraic surface.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Andrei Neguţ</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">typos fixed, presentation style improved</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.00390v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.00390v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02422v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T15:27:51Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T15:27:51Z</published>
    <title>All Weight Systems for Calabi-Yau Fourfolds from Reflexive Polyhedra</title>
    <summary>  For any given dimension $d$, all reflexive $d$-polytopes can be found (in
principle) as subpolytopes of a number of maximal polyhedra that are defined in
terms of $(d+1)$-tuples of integers (weights), or combinations of $k$-tuples of
weights with $k&lt;d+1$. We present the results of a complete classification of
sextuples of weights pertaining to the construction of all reflexive polytopes
in five dimensions. We find 322 383 760 930 such weight systems. 185 269 499
015 of them give rise directly to reflexive polytopes and thereby to mirror
pairs of Calabi-Yau fourfolds. These lead to 532 600 483 distinct sets of Hodge
numbers.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Friedrich Schöller</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Harald Skarke</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">31 pages, 30 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02422v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02422v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="hep-th" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="hep-th" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02417v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T15:22:53Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T15:22:53Z</published>
    <title>Constructible Sheaves</title>
    <summary>  This article contains a proof of the basic lemma. This lemma, discovered by
Beilinson, yields a motivic proof of the Andreotti-Frankel theorem for affine
varieties. Next, it is shown that the category of Cohomologically Constructible
Sheaves (as it is referred to in the Riemann-Hilbert correspondence) coincides
with the derived category of bounded complexes of constructible sheaves. It is
also shown that higher direct images and the sheaf-Ext groups are effaceable in
the category of constructible sheaves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Madhav V. Nori</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Published in 2002. Math reviews: MR1940678</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02417v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02417v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14-06, 14F05" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.07494v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T14:16:16Z</updated>
    <published>2015-07-27T17:32:48Z</published>
    <title>On the gonality of stable curves</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we use admissible covers to investigate the gonality of a
stable curve $C$ over $\mathbb{C}$. If $C$ is irreducible, we compare its
gonality to that of its normalization. If $C$ is reducible, we compare its
gonality to that of its irreducible components. In both cases we obtain lower
and upper bounds. Furthermore, we show that four admissible covers constructed
give rise to generically injective maps between Hurwitz schemes. We show that
the closures of the images of three of these maps are components of the
boundary of the target Hurwitz schemes, and the closure of the image of the
remaining map is a component of a certain codimension-1 subscheme of the
boundary of the target Hurwitz scheme.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Juliana Coelho</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Frederico Sercio</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">21 pages, 7 figures, comments are welcome</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.07494v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1507.07494v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14H10, 14H51" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.05540v4</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T13:43:46Z</updated>
    <published>2017-08-18T09:01:41Z</published>
    <title>Automorphisms of even unimodular lattices and equivariant Witt groups</title>
    <summary>  We characterize the irreducible polynomials that occur as a characteristic
polynomial of an automorphism of an even unimodular lattice of given signature,
generalizing a theorem of Gross and McMullen. As part of the proof, we give a
general criterion in terms of Witt groups for a bilinear form equipped with an
action of a group G over a discretely valued field to contain a unimodular
G-stable lattice.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Eva Bayer-Fluckiger</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Lenny Taelman</name>
    </author>

    <title>Finitistic test ideals on numerically $\mathbb{Q}$-Gorenstein varieties</title>
    <summary>  We prove that the finitistic test ideal $\tau_{\rm fg}(R, \Delta,
\mathfrak{a}^t)$ coincides with the big test ideal $\tau_{\rm b}(R, \Delta,
\mathfrak{a}^t)$ if the pair $(R,\Delta)$ is numerically log
$\mathbb{Q}$-Gorenstein.
</summary>

    <title>Geometry of word equations in simple algebraic groups over special
  fields</title>
    <summary>  This paper contains a survey of recent developments in investigation of word
equations in simple matrix groups and polynomial equations in simple
(associative and Lie) matrix algebras along with some new results on the image

p-adic (or close to such), or finite.

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02287v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T09:56:52Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T09:56:52Z</published>
    <title>Derived noncommutative schemes, geometric realizations, and finite
  dimensional algebras</title>
    <summary>  The main purpose of this paper is to describe various phenomena and certain
constructions arising in the process of studying derived noncommutative
schemes. Derived noncommutative schemes are defined as differential graded
categories of a special type. We review and discuss different properties of
both noncommutative schemes and morphisms between them. In addition, the
concept of geometric realization for derived noncommutative scheme is
introduced and problems of existence and construction of such realizations are
discussed. We also study the construction of gluing noncommutative schemes via
morphisms and consider some new phenomena, such as phantoms, quasi-phantoms,
and Krull-Schmidt partners, arising in the world of noncommutative schemes and
allowing us to find new noncommutative schemes. In the last sections we
consider noncommutative schemes that are related to basic finite dimensional
algebras. It is proved that such noncommutative schemes have special geometric
realizations under which the algebra goes to a vector bundle on a smooth
projective scheme. Such realizations are constructed in two steps, one of which
is the well-known construction of M. Auslander, while the second step is
connected with a new concept of a well-formed quasi-hereditary algebra for
which there are very particular geometric realizations sending standard modules
to line bundles.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Dmitri Orlov</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">50 pages, Dedicated to the blessed memory of my friend Vladimir
  Voevodsky</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02287v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02287v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.RA" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14A22, 14F05, 16E45, 18E30" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02278v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T09:42:20Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T09:42:20Z</published>
    <title>Unramified affine Springer fibers and isospectral Hilbert schemes</title>
    <summary>  For any connected reductive group $G$ over $\mathbb{C}$, we revisit
Goresky-Kottwitz-MacPherson's description of the torus equivariant (co)homology
of affine Springer fibers $\mathrm{Sp}_\gamma\subset \mathrm{Gr}_G$, where
$\gamma=at^d$, and $a$ is a regular semisimple element in the Lie algebra of
$G$. In the case $G = GL_n$, we relate the equivariant cohomology of
$\mathrm{Sp}_\gamma$ to Haiman's work on the isospectral Hilbert scheme of
points on the plane. We also explain the connection to the HOMFLY homology of
$(n, dn)$-torus links, and formulate a conjecture describing the homology of
the Hilbert scheme of points on the curve $\{x^n=y^{dn}\}$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Oscar Kivinen</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">36 pages, comments welcome</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02278v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02278v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.RT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.01009v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T09:26:04Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-03T08:11:42Z</published>
    <title>Representations of Affine Group Schemes Over General Rings</title>
    <summary>  Among all affine, flat, finitely presented group schemes, we focus on those
that are pure, this includes all groups which are extensions of a finite
locally free group by a group with connected fibres. We prove that over an
arbitrary base ring, pure group schemes have a classifying space satisfying the
resolution property, an embedding into some GLn, a tensor generator for their
category of finite type representations, and can be reconstructed from their
category of projective finite type representations. In the case of an Artinian
base ring, the same is true for all affine, flat, finitely presented group
schemes, this answers a question of Conrad. We also prove that quotients of
pure groups by closed pure subgroups over an arbitrary base scheme are
Zariski-locally quasi-projective. This answers a question of Raynaud, in the
case of affine groups. We give various applications.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Giulia Battiston</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">IRMAR</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Matthieu Romagny</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">IRMAR</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">The article is withdrawn, due to an error in Thm 4.1 that has
  consequences in several of our results</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02238v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T07:27:54Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T07:27:54Z</published>
    <title>Toward an algebraic theory of Welschinger invariants</title>
    <summary>  Let $S$ be a smooth del Pezzo surface over a field $k$ of characteristic
$\neq 2, 3$. We define an invariant in the Grothendieck-Witt ring $GW(k)$ for
"counting" rational curves in a curve class $D$ of fixed positive degree (with
respect to the anti-canonical bundle $-K_S$) and containing a collection of
distinct closed points $\mathfrak{p}=\sum_ip_i$ of total degree $r:=-D\cdot
K_S-1$ on $S$. This recovers Welschinger's invariant in case $k=\mathbb{R}$ by
applying the signature map. The main result is that this quadratic invariant
depends only on the $\mathbb{A}^1$-connected component containing
$\mathfrak{p}$ in $Sym^r(S)^0(k)$, where $Sym^r(S)^0$ is the open subscheme of
$Sym^r(S)$ parametrizing geometrically reduced 0-cycles.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Marc Levine</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02238v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02238v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14F42, 55N20, 55N35" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02235v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T07:22:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T07:22:02Z</published>
    <title>The perverse filtration for the Hitchin fibration is locally constant</title>
    <summary>  We prove that the perverse Leray filtration for the Hitchin morphism is
locally constant in families, thus providing some evidence towards the validity
of the $P=W$ conjecture due to de Cataldo, Hausel and Migliorini in non Abelian
Hodge theory.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Mark Andrea A. de Cataldo</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Davesh Maulik</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">18 pages; comments are welcome!</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02235v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02235v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02226v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T06:42:39Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T06:42:39Z</published>
    <title>Local numerical equivalences and Okounkov bodies in higher dimensions</title>
    <summary>  We study what kind of local numerical properties of divisors is encoded in
the Okounkov bodies. More precisely, we show that the set of Okounkov bodies of
a pseudoeffective divisor with respect to admissible flags centered at a fixed
point determines the local numerical equivalence class of divisors which is
defined in terms of refined divisorial Zariski decompositions. Our results
extend Ro\'{e}'s work on surfaces to higher dimensional varieties.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Sung Rak Choi</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jinhyung Park</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Joonyeong Won</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">19 pages, comments are welcome!</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02226v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02226v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02172v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-07T01:05:04Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-07T01:05:04Z</published>
    <title>Algebraic tangent cones of reflexive sheaves</title>
    <summary>  We study the notion of algebraic tangent cones at singularities of reflexive
sheaves. These correspond to extensions of reflexive sheaves across a negative
divisor. We show the existence of optimal extensions in a constructive manner,
and we prove the uniqueness in a suitable sense. The results here are an
algebro-geometric counterpart of our previous study on singularities of
Hermitian-Yang-Mills connections.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Xuemiao Chen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Song Sun</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02172v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02172v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.08847v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T23:30:52Z</updated>
    <published>2015-12-30T04:30:15Z</published>
    <title>Symplectic realizations of holomorphic Poisson manifolds</title>
    <summary>  Symplectic realization is a longstanding problem which can be traced back to
Sophus Lie. In this paper, we present an explicit solution to this problem for
an arbitrary holomorphic Poisson manifold. More precisely, for any holomorphic
Poisson manifold $(X, \pi)$, we prove that there exists a holomorphic
symplectic structure in a neighborhood $Y$ of the zero section of $T^*X$ such
that the projection map is a symplectic realization of the given Poisson
manifold, and moreover the zero section is a holomorphic Lagrangian
submanifold. We describe an explicit construction for such a new holomorphic
symplectic structure on $Y \subseteq T^*X$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Damien Broka</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Ping Xu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">25 pages; minor mistakes corrected; a few new proofs added;
  presentation improved</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02150v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T23:08:37Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T23:08:37Z</published>
    <title>The image of a tropical linear space</title>
    <summary>  Given a tropical linear space $L \subseteq \mathbb{T}^n$ and a matrix $A \in
\mathbb{T}^{m \times n}$, the image $AL$ of $L$ under $A$ is typically not a
tropical linear space. We introduce a tropical linear space
$\mathrm{tropim}_A(L)$, the tropical image, containing $AL$. We show under mild
hypotheses that $\mathrm{tropim}_A(L)$ is realizable if $L$ is and apply the
tropical image to construct the stable sum of two tropical linear spaces
without a disjoint pair of bases.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Joshua Mundinger</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">19 pages, 1 figure</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02150v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02102v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T20:41:56Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T20:41:56Z</published>
    <title>On the boundedness of anti-canonical volumes of singular Fano $3$-folds
  in characteristic $p&gt;5$</title>
    <summary>  In this article we prove the following version of the Weak-BAB conjecture for
$3$-folds in char $p&gt;5$: Fix a DCC set $I\subset [0, 1)$ and an algebraically
closed field $k$ of characteristic $p&gt;5$. Let $\mathfrak{D}$ be a collection of
klt pairs $(X, \Delta)$ satisfying the following properties: (1) $X$ is a
projective $3$-fold, (2) $\Delta$ is an $\mathbb{R}$-divisor with coefficients
in $I$, (3) $K_X+\Delta\equiv 0$, and (4) $-K_X$ is ample. Then the set
$\{\mbox{vol}_X(-K_X) \ | \ (X, \Delta)\in\mathfrak{D}\mbox{ for some
}\Delta\}$ is bounded from above.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Omprokash Das</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02102v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02102v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02067v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T18:49:09Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T18:49:09Z</published>
    <title>Dagger completions and bornological torsion-freeness</title>
    <summary>  We define a dagger algebra as a bornological algebra over a discrete
valuation ring with three properties that are typical of Monsky-Washnitzer
algebras, namely, completeness, bornological torsion-freeness and a certain
spectral radius condition. We study inheritance properties of the three
properties that define a dagger algebra. We describe dagger completions of
bornological algebras in general and compute some noncommutative examples.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ralf Meyer</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Devarshi Mukherjee</name>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.02040v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T18:00:05Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T18:00:05Z</published>
    <title>A 3d Gauge Theory/Quantum K-Theory Correspondence</title>
    <summary>  The 2d gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) gives a UV model for quantum
cohomology on a Kahler manifold X, which is reproduced in the IR limit. We
propose and explore a 3d lift of this correspondence, where the UV model is the
N=2 supersymmetric 3d gauge theory and the IR limit is given by Givental's
permutation equivariant quantum K-theory on X. This gives a one-parameter
deformation of the 2d GLSM/quantum cohomology correspondence and recovers it in
a small radius limit. We study some novelties of the 3d case regarding integral
BPS invariants, chiral rings, deformation spaces and mirror symmetry.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hans Jockers</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Peter Mayr</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">111 pages</arxiv:comment>

    <title>Moduli of filtered quiver representations</title>
    <summary>  In this note, we give a construction of the moduli space of filtered repre-
sentations of a given quiver of fixed dimension vector with the appropriate
notion of stability. The construction of the moduli of filtered representation
uses the moduli of representation of ladder quiver. The ladder quiver is
introduced using the given quiver and a linear type quiver.
</summary>

    <title>On the anticanonical complex</title>
    <summary>  The anticanonical complex has been introduced as a natural generalisation of
the toric Fano polytope and so far has been succesfully used for the study of
varieties with a torus action of complexity one. In the present article we
enlarge the area of application of the anticanonical complex to varieties with
a torus action of higher complexity, for example, arrangement varieties.
</summary>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.03281v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T16:54:41Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-09T17:33:02Z</published>
    <title>Exodromy</title>
    <summary>  Let $X$ be a scheme. Let $\operatorname{Gal}(X)$ be the topological category
whose objects are geometric points of $X$ and whose morphisms are
specialisations thereof. If $X$ is a scheme of finite type over a finitely
generated field $k$ of characteristic zero, then the category
$\operatorname{Gal}(X)$ acquires a continuous action of the absolute Galois
group $G_k$ of $k$. Our main result is that the resulting functor from reduced
normal schemes of finite type over $k$ to topological categories with an action
of $G_k$ is fully faithful.
  The category $\operatorname{Gal}(X)$ is a form of MacPherson's exit-path
category for the \'etale topology. 'Exodromy' refers to the equivalence between
representations of $\operatorname{Gal}(X)$ and constructible sheaves on $X$.
Together with a higher categorical form of Hochster Duality, this equivalence
ensures that the entire \'etale topos of a coherent scheme can be reconstructed
from $\operatorname{Gal}(X)$. Voevodsky's proof of a conjecture of Grothendieck
then implies our main theorem.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Clark Barwick</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Saul Glasman</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Peter Haine</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Comments very welcome. v2: 126 pages. New abstract. Corrected a
  number of typos, expanded on a few points, and added a subsection on the
  canonical stratification of a coherent $\infty$-topos. v1: 120 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.03281v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.03281v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01987v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T16:41:33Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T16:41:33Z</published>
    <title>Idempotent Analysis, Tropical Convexity and Reduced Divisors</title>
    <summary>  We investigate a canonical extension of a conventional combinatorial notion
of reduced divisors to a notion of tropical projections, which can be defined
as the unique minimizers of the so-called $B$-pseudonorms with respect to
compact tropical convex sets. In this paper, we build the foundation of a
theory of idempotent analysis using tropical projections and obtain a series of
subsequent results, e.g. tropical retracts, construction of compact tropical
convex sets and a set-theoretical characterization of tropical independence. In
particular, we prove a tropical version of Mazur's Theorem on closed tropical
convex hulls and discover a fixed point theorem for tropical projections. As
the main application of our machinery of tropical convexity analysis, we
investigate the divisor theory on metric graphs based on tropical projections.
We extend the notion of linear systems and redefine the notion of reduced
divisors to all linear systems instead of only to complete linear systems.
Moreover, we explore the correspondence between reduced divisor maps to
dominant tropical trees and harmonic morphisms to metric trees. Furthermore, we
propose a notion called the geometric rank for linear systems on metric graphs
which resolves the discrepancy between the interpretations of gonality of
metric graphs using the conventional Baker-Norine rank function and using
harmonic morphisms to metric trees.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ye Luo</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">65 pages, 7 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01987v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01987v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.CO" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CO" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10390v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T09:11:46Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-26T22:37:08Z</published>
    <title>The Distance Function from a Real Algebraic Variety</title>
    <summary>  For any (real) algebraic variety $X$ in a Euclidean space $V$ endowed with a
nondegenerate quadratic form $q$, we introduce a polynomial
$\mathrm{EDpoly}_{X,u}(t^2)$ which, for any $u\in V$, has among its roots the
distance from $u$ to $X$. The degree of $\mathrm{EDpoly}_{X,u}$ is the
Euclidean Distance degree of $X$. We prove a duality property when $X$ is a
projective variety, namely
$\mathrm{EDpoly}_{X,u}(t^2)=\mathrm{EDpoly}_{X^{\vee},u}(q(u)-t^2)$ where
$X^{\vee}$ is the dual variety of $X$. When $X$ is transversal to the isotropic
quadric $Q$, we prove that the ED polynomial of $X$ is monic and the zero locus
of its lower term is $X\cup(X^{\vee}\cap Q)^{\vee}$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Giorgio Ottaviani</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Luca Sodomaco</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">21 pages, 4 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.10390v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.10390v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14C17, 14P05, 15A72, 58K05, 90C26" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01719v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T03:12:10Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T03:12:10Z</published>
    <title>A formula for the cohomology and $K$-class of a regular Hessenberg
  variety</title>
    <summary>  Hessenberg varieties are subvarieties of the flag variety parametrized by a
linear operator $X$ and a nondecreasing function $h$. The family of Hessenberg
varieties for regular $X$ is particularly important: they are used in quantum
cohomology, in combinatorial and geometric representation theory, in Schubert
calculus and affine Schubert calculus. We show that the classes of a regular
Hessenberg variety in the cohomology and $K$-theory of the flag variety are
given by making certain substitutions in the Schubert polynomial (respectively
Grothendieck polynomial) for a permutation that depends only on $h$. Our
formula and our methods are different from a recent result of Abe, Fujita, and
Zeng that gives the class of a regular Hessenberg variety with more
restrictions on $h$ than here.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Erik Insko</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Julianna Tymoczko</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Alexander Woo</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">14 pages, no figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01719v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
