  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01704v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-06T01:02:36Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-06T01:02:36Z</published>
    <title>Constructing Endomorphism Rings of Large Finite Global Dimension</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we study endomorphism rings of finite global dimension over a
ring associated to a numerical semigroup. We construct these endomorphism rings
in two ways, called the lazy and greedy construction. The first main result of
this paper shows that the lazy construction enables us to obtain endomorphism
rings of arbitrarily large global dimension. The second main result of this
paper shows that the greedy construction gives us endomorphism rings which
always have global dimension two. As a consequence, for a fixed numerical
semigroup, the difference of the maximal possible value and the minimal
possible value of the global dimension of an endomorphism ring over that
numerical semigroup can be arbitrarily large.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ali Mousavidehshikh</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01704v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01704v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01692v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T22:13:55Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T22:13:55Z</published>
    <title>Projectively unique polytopes and toric slack ideals</title>
    <summary>  The slack ideal of a polytope is a saturated determinantal ideal that gives
rise to a new model for the realization space of the polytope. The simplest
slack ideals are toric and have connections to projectively unique polytopes.
We prove that if a projectively unique polytope has a toric slack ideal, then
it is the toric ideal of the bipartite graph of vertex-facet non-incidences of
the polytope. The slack ideal of a polytope is contained in this toric ideal if
and only if the polytope is morally 2-level, a generalization of the 2-level
property in polytopes. We show that polytopes that do not admit rational
realizations cannot have toric slack ideals. A classical example of a
projectively unique polytope with no rational realizations is due to Perles. We
prove that the slack ideal of the Perles polytope is reducible, providing the
first example of a slack ideal that is not prime.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>João Gouveia</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Antonio Macchia</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Rekha R. Thomas</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Amy Wiebe</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Parts of this paper originally appeared in the first version of
  arXiv:1708.04739 [math.CO]. That paper was subsequently split into two:
  arXiv:1708.04739[math.CO] describing the slack realization space of a
  polytope &amp; applications of the slack ideal, and this paper focussing on toric
  slack ideals &amp; projective uniqueness. In addition, this paper contains the
  first example of a reducible slack ideal</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01692v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01692v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.CO" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CO" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.04739v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T21:57:32Z</updated>
    <published>2017-08-16T01:45:57Z</published>
    <title>The Slack Realization Space of a Polytope</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we introduce a natural model for the realization space of a
polytope up to projective equivalence which we call the slack realization space
of the polytope. The model arises from the positive part of an algebraic
variety determined by the slack ideal of the polytope. This is a saturated
determinantal ideal that encodes the combinatorics of the polytope. We also
derive a new model of the realization space of a polytope from the positive
part of the variety of a related ideal. The slack ideal offers an effective
computational framework for several classical questions about polytopes such as
rational realizability, non-prescribability of faces, and realizability of
combinatorial polytopes.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>João Gouveia</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Antonio Macchia</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Rekha R. Thomas</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Amy Wiebe</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">The original arXiv submission of this paper has now been split into
  two parts; this paper describing the slack realization space of a polytope
  and applications of the slack ideal, and a second paper focussing on toric
  slack ideals and projective uniqueness</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.04739v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01689v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T21:44:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T21:44:02Z</published>
    <title>On elliptic modular foliations, II</title>
    <summary>  We give an example of a one dimensional foliation $\cal F$ of degree two in a
Zariski open set of a four dimensional weighted projective space which has only
an enumerable set of algebraic leaves. These are defined over rational numbers
and are isomorphic to modular curves $X_0(d),\ d\in\Bbb B$ minus cusp points.
As a by-product we get new models for modular curves for which we slightly
modify an argument due to J. V. Pereira and give closed formulas for elements
in their defining ideals. The general belief has been that such formulas do not
exist and the emphasis in the literature has been on introducing faster
algorithms to compute equations for small values of $d$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hossein Movasati</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01689v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01689v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CV" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

    <title>Lebesgue currents</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we introduce the notion of Lebesgue currents. They are a
special type of currents involving the Lebesgue measure.
</summary>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11680v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T17:17:51Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-31T06:47:40Z</published>
    <title>Differentiability of the arithmetic volume function along the base
  conditions</title>
    <summary>  The arithmetic volume of a pair of an adelic R-Cartier divisor and an
R-Cartier divisor is an invariant measuring the asymptotic behavior of the
numbers of the strictly small sections of the high multiples of the pair. In
this paper, we establish that the arithmetic volume function defined on an open
cone of the space of pairs is Gateaux differentiable along the directions of
R-Cartier divisors and that the derivatives are given by arithmetic restricted
positive intersection numbers.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hideaki Ikoma</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">37 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11680v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.11680v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.07176v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T12:01:35Z</updated>
    <published>2018-04-19T13:58:29Z</published>
    <title>Some implications between Grothendieck's anabelian conjectures</title>
    <summary>  The main result of this paper is to establish two implications between
Grothendieck's anabelian conjectures. We define anabelian Deligne-Mumford
stacks as those DM stacks that satisfy the section conjecture in a strong
sense: for schemes, this amounts to the section conjecture plus triviality of
the centralizers of sections. We prove that anabelian DM stacks satisfy the hom
conjecture (which characterizes morphisms from a smooth scheme $T$ to an
anabelian variety, or DM stack $X$). As a corollary, for hyperbolic curves the
section conjecture implies the hom conjecture. In doing this, we actually show
that for $T$ normality is enough. We show that if a positive dimensional DM
stack is anabelian then its geometric fundamental group cannot have abelian
finite index subgroups. We enlarge the class of elementary anabelian varieties
to elementary anabelian DM stacks. We prove that they satisfy the injectivity
part of the conjecture, and that the section conjecture for hyperbolic curves
implies that elementary anabelian DM stacks satisfy the section conjecture too.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Giulio Bresciani</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.07176v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1804.07176v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05758v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T11:46:48Z</updated>
    <published>2018-01-17T17:10:26Z</published>
    <title>On Grothendieck's section conjecture for orbicurves</title>
    <summary>  As already noted by Niels Borne and Michel Emsalem, there is a natural
generalization of the section conjecture for proper orbicurves. Combined with
the reformulation by Niels Borne and Angelo Vistoli of the conjecture in terms
of the \'etale fundamental gerbe, this suggests an even stronger conjecture for
orbicurves, asking an equivalence of categories instead of a mere bijection. We
prove that the three versions of the conjecture are in fact equivalent, and
that "injectivity" (i.e. full faithfulness) holds in the case of orbicurves. As
a byproduct, we obtain a new proof of the fact that the section conjecture for
proper curves implies the section conjecture for open curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Giulio Bresciani</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05758v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.05758v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01594v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T10:19:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T10:19:02Z</published>
    <title>Degenerate Schubert Varieties in Type A</title>
    <summary>  We introduce rectangular elements in the symmetric group. In the framework of
PBW degenerations, we show that in type A the degenerate Schubert variety
associated to a rectangular element is indeed a Schubert variety in a partial
flag variety of the same type with larger rank. Moreover, the degenerate
Demazure module associated to a rectangular element is isomorphic to the
Demazure module for this particular Schubert variety of larger rank. This
generalizes previous results by Cerulli Irelli, Lanini and Littelmann for the
PBW degenerate flag variety.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Rocco Chirivi'</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Xin Fang</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Ghislain Fourier</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">26 pages, 6 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01594v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01593v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T10:10:21Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T10:10:21Z</published>
    <title>Explicit Rational Group Law on Hyperelliptic Jacobians of any Genus</title>
    <summary>  It is well-known that abelian varieties are projective, and so that there
exist explicit polynomial and rational functions which define both the variety
and its group law. It is however difficult to find any explicit polynomial and
rational functions describing these varieties or their group laws in dimensions
greater than two. One exception can be found in Mumford's classic "Lectures on
Theta", where he describes how to obtain an explicit model for hyperelliptic
Jacobians as the union of several affine pieces described as the vanishing
locus of explicit polynomial equations. In this article, we extend this work to
give explicit equations for the group law on a dense open set. One can view
these equations as generalizations of the usual chord-based group law on
elliptic curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>David Urbanik</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">The work has associated source code, a link to which is included in
  the references, and can be found at
  csclub.uwaterloo.ca/~dburbani/work/jacarith_dburbani_August2018.zip</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01593v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01593v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.07457v6</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T06:39:55Z</updated>
    <published>2015-07-27T15:46:52Z</published>
    <title>Planar 2-homogeneous commutative rational vector fields</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we prove the following result: if two 2-dimensional
2-homogeneous rational vector fields commute, then either both vector fields
can be explicitly integrated to produce rational flows with orbits being lines
through the origin, or both flows can be explicitly integrated in terms of
algebraic functions. In the latter case, orbits of each flow are given in terms
of $1$-homogeneous rational functions $W$ as curves $W(x,y)=\textrm{const}$. An
exhaustive method to construct such commuting algebraic flows is presented. The
degree of the so-obtained algebraic functions in two variables can be
arbitrarily high.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Giedrius Alkauskas</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Vilnius</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">23 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:journal_ref xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Electronic Journal Differential Equations, Vol. 2018 (2018), No.
  138, pp. 1-21</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1507.07457v6" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1507.07457v6" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CA" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01549v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T01:39:49Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T01:39:49Z</published>
    <title>On Fano complete intersections in rational homogeneous varieties</title>
    <summary>  Complete intersections inside rational homogeneous varieties provide
interesting examples of Fano manifolds. For example, if $X = \cap_{i=1}^r D_i
\subset G/P$ is a general complete intersection of $r$ ample divisors such that
$K_{G/P}^* \otimes \mathcal{O}_{G/P}(-\sum_i D_i)$ is ample, then $X$ is Fano.
We first classify these Fano complete intersections which are locally rigid. It
turns out that most of them are hyperplane sections. We then classify general
hyperplane sections which are quasi-homogeneous.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Chenyu Bai</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Baohua Fu</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Laurent Manivel</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01549v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01549v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01547v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-05T01:25:50Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-05T01:25:50Z</published>
    <title>Asymptotic resurgence via integral closures</title>
    <summary>  Given an ideal in a polynomial ring, we show that the asymptotic resurgence
studied by Guardo, Harbourne, and Van Tuyl can be computed using integral
closures. As a consequence, the asymptotic resurgence of an ideal is the
maximum of finitely many ratios involving Waldschmidt-like constants (which we
call skew Waldschmidt constants) defined in terms of Rees valuations. We use
this to prove that the asymptotic resurgence coincides with the resurgence if
the ideal is normal (that is, all its powers are integrally closed).
  For a monomial ideal the skew Waldschmidt constants have an interpretation
involving the symbolic polyhedron defined by Cooper, Embree, H\`a, and Hoefel.
Using this intuition we provide several examples of squarefree monomial ideals
whose resurgence and asymptotic resurgence are different.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Michael DiPasquale</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Christopher A. Francisco</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jeffrey Mermin</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jay Schweig</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">21 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01547v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01547v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.03146v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-04T21:36:22Z</updated>
    <published>2017-01-11T20:12:59Z</published>
    <title>Quantum q-Langlands Correspondence</title>
    <summary>  We formulate a two-parameter generalization of the geometric Langlands
correspondence, which we prove for all simply-laced Lie algebras. It identifies
the q-conformal blocks of the quantum affine algebra and the deformed W-algebra
associated to two Langlands dual Lie algebras. Our proof relies on recent
results in quantum K-theory of the Nakajima quiver varieties. The physical
origin of the correspondence is the 6d little string theory. The quantum
Langlands correspondence emerges in the limit in which the 6d string theory
becomes the 6d conformal field theory with (2,0) supersymmetry.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Mina Aganagic</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Edward Frenkel</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Andrei Okounkov</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">116 pages, 4 figures. Minor changes. Version accepted for publication
  in Trudy Moskovskogo Matematicheskogo Obshchestva. (Transactions of the
  Moscow Mathematical Society.)</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.03146v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1701.03146v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.00978v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-04T21:19:52Z</updated>
    <published>2017-09-04T14:30:59Z</published>
    <title>Chtoucas restreints pour les groupes réductifs et paramétrisation de
  Langlands locale</title>
    <summary>  We associate to every irreducible representation of a reductive group over a
local field of equal characteristics a local Langlands parameter up to
semisimplification and prove the compatibility with the global parameterization
constructed by the second author. Our method involves stacks of restricted
shtukas (which are analogues of truncated Barsotti-Tate groups) and nearby
cycles over arbitrary bases.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Alain Genestier</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Vincent Lafforgue</name>
    </author>

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01508v1</id>

    <title>Cohomology of line bundles on horospherical varieties</title>
    <summary>  A horospherical variety is a normal algebraic variety where a connected
reductive algebraic group acts with an open orbit isomorphic to a torus bundle
over a flag variety. In this article we study the cohomology of line bundles on
complete horospherical varieties.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Benoît Dejoncheere</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>B. Narasimha Chary</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Comments are welcome!</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07142v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-04T09:02:30Z</updated>
    <published>2017-02-23T09:14:37Z</published>
    <title>On the group of purely inseparable points of an abelian variety defined
  over a function field of positive characteristic II</title>
    <summary>  Let $A$ be an abelian variety over the function field $K$ of a curve over a
finite field. We describe several mild geometric conditions ensuring that the
group $A(K^{\rm perf})$ is finitely generated and that the $p$-primary torsion
subgroup of $A(K^{\rm sep})$ is finite. This gives partial answers to questions
of Scanlon, Ghioca and Moosa, and Poonen and Voloch. We also describe a simple
theory (used to prove our results) relating the Harder-Narasimhan filtration of
vector bundles to the structure of finite flat group schemes of height one over
projective curves over perfect fields. Finally, we use our results to give a
complete proof of a conjecture of Esnault and Langer on Verschiebung
divisibility of points in abelian varieties over function fields in the
situation where the base field is the algebraic closure of a finite field.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Damian Rössler</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">44 pages; the previous version's results on the conjecture of Esnault
  and Langer were less general</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07142v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.07142v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.07558v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-04T06:17:21Z</updated>
    <published>2018-04-20T11:41:06Z</published>
    <title>Cohomology of ideals in elliptic surface singularities</title>
    <summary>  We introduce the the normal reduction number of two-dimensional normal
singularities and prove that elliptic singularity has normal reduction number
two. We also prove that for a two-dimensional normal singularity which is not
rational, it is Gorenstein and its maximal ideal is a $p_g$-ideal if and only
if it is a maximally elliptic singularity of degree $1$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Tomohiro Okuma</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">15 pages; various corrections and improvements. To appear in Illinois
  J. Math</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.07558v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1804.07558v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.02406v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-04T06:15:14Z</updated>
    <published>2018-01-08T12:39:22Z</published>
    <title>Tate's conjecture and the Tate-Shafarevich group over global function
  fields</title>
    <summary>  Let $\mathcal X$ be a regular variety, flat and proper over a complete
regular curve over a finite field, such that the generic fiber $X$ is smooth
and geometrically connected. We prove that the Brauer group of $\mathcal X$ is
finite if and only Tate's conjecture for divisors on $X$ holds and the
Tate-Shafarevich group of the Albanese variety of $X$ is finite, generalizing a
theorem of Artin and Grothendieck for surfaces to arbitrary relative dimension.
We also give a formula relating the orders of the group under the assumption
that they are finite, generalizing the formula given for a surface.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Thomas H. Geisser</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Completely rewritten</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.02406v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.02406v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.NT" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11437v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T20:30:18Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-30T16:52:36Z</published>
    <title>Harer-Zagier formula via Fock space</title>
    <summary>  The goal of this note is to provide a very short proof of Harer-Zagier
formula for the number of ways of obtaining a genus g Riemann surface by
identifying in pairs the sides of a (2d)-gon, using semi-infinite wedge
formalism operators.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Danilo Lewanski</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">5 pages, comments are welcome</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11437v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.11437v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.08366v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T18:04:30Z</updated>
    <published>2017-05-23T15:33:45Z</published>
    <title>A Bogomolov unobstructedness theorem for log-symplectic manifolds in
  general position</title>
    <summary>  We consider compact K\"ahlerian manifolds $X$ of even dimension 4 or more,
endowed with a log-symplectic holomorphic Poisson structure $\Pi$ which is
sufficiently general, in a precise linear sense, with respect to its
(normal-crossing) degeneracy divisor $D(\Pi)$. We prove that $(X, \Pi)$ has
unobsrtuced deformations, that the tangent space to its deformation space can
be identified in terms of the mixed Hodge structure on $H^2$ of the open
symplectic manifold $X\setminus D(\Pi)$, and in fact coincides with this $H^2$
provided the Hodge number $h^{2,0}_X=0$, and finally that the degeneracy locus
$D(\Pi)$ deforms locally trivially under deformations of $(X, \Pi)$. \
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ziv Ran</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">To appear in J. Inst. Math. Jussieu</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.08366v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1705.08366v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14J40, 32G07, 32J27, 53D17" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.8153v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T18:03:09Z</updated>
    <published>2014-12-28T12:11:01Z</published>
    <title>On terminal Fano 3-folds with 2-torus action</title>
    <summary>  We classify the terminal Fano threefolds of Picard number one that come with
an effective action of a two-torus. Our approach applies also to higher
dimensions and generalizes the correspondence between toric Fano varieties and
lattice polytopes: to any Fano variety with a complete intersection Cox ring we
associate its "anti canonical complex", which is a certain polyhedral complex
living in the lattice of one parameter groups of an ambient toric variety. For
resolutions constructed via the tropical variety, the lattice points inside the
anticanonical complex control the discrepancies. This leads, for example, to
simple characterizations of terminality and canonicity.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Benjamin Bechtold</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Elaine Huggenberger</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Juergen Hausen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Michele Nicolussi</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">missing items in the classification list added, other corrections</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:journal_ref xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">IMRN 2016 (5), 1563-1602, Corrigendum IMRN 2017 (19) 6086-6087</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1412.8153v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1412.8153v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01290v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T18:00:31Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-03T18:00:31Z</published>
    <title>The strong maximal rank conjecture and moduli spaces of curves</title>
    <summary>  Building on recent work of the authors, we use degenerations to chains of
elliptic curves to prove two cases of the Aprodu-Farkas strong maximal rank
conjecture. It follows by work of Farkas that the moduli spaces of curves of
genus 22 and 23 are of general type. Our techniques involve a combination of
the Eisenbud-Harris theory of limit linear series, and the notion of linked
linear series developed by the second author.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Fu Liu</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Brian Osserman</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Naizhen Zhang</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01285v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T18:00:06Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-03T18:00:06Z</published>
    <title>Effectivity of Farkas classes and the Kodaira dimensions of M_{22} and
  M_{23}</title>
    <summary>  We develop new methods to study tropicalizations of linear series and show
linear independence of algebraic sections. Using these methods, we prove two
outstanding cases of the strong maximal rank conjecture and verify that certain
divisor classes on M_{22} and M_{23} identified by Farkas are represented by
effective divisors. This completes Farkas's program to show that the moduli
spaces of curves of genus 22 and 23 are of general type.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>David Jensen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Sam Payne</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">65 pages, 21 figures</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.00225v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T15:56:45Z</updated>
    <published>2016-10-02T05:50:20Z</published>
    <title>Quantizing Weierstrass</title>
    <summary>  We study the connection between the Eynard-Orantin topological recursion and
quantum curves for the family of genus one spectral curves given by the
Weierstrass equation. We construct quantizations of the spectral curve that
annihilate the perturbative and non-perturbative wave-functions. In particular,
for the non-perturbative wave-function, we prove, up to order hbar^5, that the
quantum curve satisfies the properties expected from matrix models. As a side
result, we obtain an infinite sequence of identities relating A-cycle integrals
of elliptic functions and quasi-modular forms.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Vincent Bouchard</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Nitin K. Chidambaram</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Tyler Dauphinee</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:doi xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">10.4310/CNTP.2018.v12.n2.a2</arxiv:doi>
    <link title="doi" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.4310/CNTP.2018.v12.n2.a2" rel="related"/>

    <title>Integral Hasse principle and strong approximation for Markoff surfaces</title>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01179v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T13:10:45Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-03T13:10:45Z</published>
    <title>Two polarized K3 surfaces associated to the same cubic fourfold</title>
    <summary>  For infinitely many $d$, Hassett showed that special cubic fourfolds of
discriminant $d$ are related to polarized K3 surfaces of degree $d$ via their
Hodge structures. For half of the $d$, a generic special cubic has not one but
two different associated K3 surfaces $(S,L)$ and $(S^{\tau},L^{\tau})$. We
prove that $S^{\tau}$ is isomorphic to the moduli space of stable coherent
sheaves on $S$ with Mukai vector $(3,L,d/6)$. We also explain for which $d$ the
Hilbert schemes $\text{Hilb}^2(S)$ and $\text{Hilb}^2(S^{\tau})$ are
isomorphic.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Emma Brakkee</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01179v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01179v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.04022v6</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T12:52:57Z</updated>
    <published>2016-10-13T11:03:31Z</published>
    <title>Bounds for elimination of unknowns in systems of differential-algebraic
  equations</title>
    <summary>  Elimination of unknowns in systems of equations, starting with Gaussian
elimination, is a problem of general interest. The problem of finding an a
priori upper bound for the number of differentiations in elimination of
unknowns in a system of differential-algebraic equations (DAEs) is an important
challenge, going back to Ritt (1932). The first characterization of this via an
asymptotic analysis is due to Grigoriev's result (1989) on quantifier
elimination in differential fields, but the challenge still remained.
  In this paper, we present a new bound, which is a major improvement over the
previously known results. We also present a new lower bound, which shows
asymptotic tightness of our upper bound in low dimensions, which are frequently
occurring in applications. Finally, we discuss applications of our results to
designing new algorithms for elimination of unknowns in systems of DAEs.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Alexey Ovchinnikov</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Gleb Pogudin</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>N. Thieu Vo</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.04022v6" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1610.04022v6" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="cs.SC" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="12H05, 12H20, 14Q20, 34A09" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.10105v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T12:13:31Z</updated>
    <published>2018-06-26T16:46:59Z</published>
    <title>Degeneration of Kummer surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We prove that a Kummer surface defined over a complete strictly Henselian
discretely valued field $K$ of residue characteristic different from 2 admits a
strict Kulikov model after finite base change. The Kulikov models we construct
will be schemes, so our results imply that the semistable reduction conjecture
is true for Kummer surfaces in this setup, even in the category of schemes. Our
construction of Kulikov models is closely related to an earlier construction of
K\"unnemann, which produces semistable models of Abelian varieties. It is
well-known that the special fibre of a strict Kulikov model belongs to one of
three types, and we shall prove that the type of the special fibre of a strict
Kulikov model of a Kummer surface and the toric rank of a corresponding Abelian
surface are determined by each other. We also study the relationship between
this invariant and the Galois representation on the second $\ell$-adic
cohomology of the Kummer surface. Finally, we apply our results, together with
earlier work of Halle-Nicaise, to give a proof of the monodromy conjecture for
Kummer surfaces in equal characteristic zero.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Otto Overkamp</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">38 pages. Some typographical errors fixed. Small correction to the
  proof of Lemma 3.10</arxiv:comment>

    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1302.6710v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T10:28:13Z</updated>

    <title>Surfaces that are covered by two families of circles</title>
    <summary>  We classify real surfaces that contain at least two circles through a general
point. Our main Moebius invariant is the Neron-Severi lattice enhanced with an
involution coming from the real structure.
</summary>
    <author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.11116v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T09:35:19Z</updated>
    <published>2017-10-30T17:58:34Z</published>
    <title>Brauer--Manin obstructions on degree 2 K3 surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We analyze the Brauer--Manin obstruction to rational points on the K3
surfaces over $\mathbb{Q}$ given by double covers of $\mathbb{P}^2$ ramified
over a diagonal sextic. After finding an explicit set of generators for the
geometric Picard group of such a surface, we find two types of infinite
families of counterexamples to the Hasse principle explained by the algebraic
Brauer--Manin obstruction. The first type of obstruction comes from a
quaternion algebra, and the second type comes from a 3-torsion element of the
Brauer group, which gives an affirmative answer to a question asked by
Ieronymou and Skorobogatov.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Patrick Corn</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Masahiro Nakahara</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Fixed minor errors in text and small changes in wording</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.11116v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>

    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01115v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-03T08:23:56Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-03T08:23:56Z</published>
    <title>Maps from K-trivial varieties and connectedness problems</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we study varieties covered by rational or elliptic curves.
First, we show that images of Calabi-Yau or irreducible symplectic varieties
under rational maps are almost always rationally connected. Second, we
investigate elliptically connected and elliptically chain connected varieties,
and varieties swept out by a family of elliptic curves. Among other things, we
show that Calabi-Yau or hyperk\"ahler manifolds which are covered by a family
of elliptic curves contain uniruled divisors and that elliptically chain
connected varieties of dimension at least two contain a rational curve, and so
do K-trivial varieties with finite fundamental group which are covered by
elliptic curves.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Vladimir Lazić</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Thomas Peternell</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">27 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01115v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01115v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14J32, 14H10" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01037v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T22:12:41Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T22:12:41Z</published>
    <title>Stokes shells and Fourier transforms</title>
    <summary>  We introduce the notion of Stokes shells describing the irregular singularity
of meromorphic flat bundles on a punctured disc. We apply it to the study of
the Fourier transform of holonomic D-modules on a complex projective line.
Namely, we explicitly describe the Stokes structure at infinity of the Fourier
transform of such D-modules as a successive extensions of Stokes shells.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Takuro Mochizuki</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01037v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.01037v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CA" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CV" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.03301v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T18:22:27Z</updated>
    <published>2015-03-11T12:38:06Z</published>
    <title>Minimal surface singularities are Lipschitz normally embedded</title>
    <summary>  Any germ of a complex analytic space is equipped with two natural metrics:
the {\it outer metric} induced by the hermitian metric of the ambient space and
the {\it inner metric}, which is the associated riemannian metric on the germ.
We show that minimal surface singularities are Lipschitz normally embedded
(LNE), i.e., the identity map is a bilipschitz homeomorphism between outer and
inner metrics, and that they are the only rational surface singularities with
this property.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Walter D Neumann</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Helge Møller Pedersen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Anne Pichon</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">This paper is a major revision of the 2015 version. It now builds on
  the paper arXiv:1806.11240 by the same authors which gives a general
  characterization of Lipschitz normally embedded surface singularities</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.03301v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1503.03301v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14B05, 32S25, 32S05, 57M99" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00885v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T16:20:35Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T16:20:35Z</published>
    <title>Kodaira dimensions of almost complex manifolds</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we introduce the plurigenera, Kodaira dimensions and more
generally Iitaka dimensions on compact almost complex manifolds. These are
equal to the original notions when the almost complex structure is integrable.
The definitions are based on the Hodge theory on almost complex manifolds. An
alternative interpretation using pseudoholomorphic maps leads to fundamental
geometric consequences.
  We show that the plurigenera and the Kodaira dimension as well as the
irregularity are birational invariants in almost complex category, at least in
dimension $4$, where a birational morphism is defined to be a degree one
pseudoholomorphic map. However, they are no longer deformation invariants, even
in dimension $4$ or under tameness assumption. For tamed almost complex
$4$-manifolds, our Kodaira dimension is bounded above by the symplectic Kodaira
dimension.
  By studying pluricanonical maps, we are able to show the almost complex
structures that achieve the top Kodaira dimension are integrable. On the other
hand, the Kodaira dimension could take all the other possible integer values
for non-integrable almost complex structures.
  When we apply our invariants to the standard almost complex structure on the
six sphere $S^6$, we show the Kodaira dimension is $0$ and all the plurigenera
are $1$, which is different from the data of a hypothetical complex structure.
  In the appendix, we show the uniqueness of subvarieties in exceptional curve
classes for irrational symplectic $4$-manifolds, which was a question of the
second author.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Haojie Chen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Weiyi Zhang</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">52+5 pages, 1 appendix</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00885v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00885v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.DG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.DG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CV" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.SG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00879v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T16:01:57Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T16:01:57Z</published>
    <title>Odd order obstructions to the Hasse principle on general K3 surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We show that odd order transcendental elements of the Brauer group of a K3
surface can obstruct the Hasse principle. We exhibit a general K3 surface $Y$
of degree 2 over $\mathbb{Q}$ together with a three torsion Brauer class
$\alpha$ that is unramified at all primes except for 3, but ramifies at all
3-adic points of $Y$. Motivated by Hodge theory, the pair $(Y, \alpha)$ is
constructed from a cubic fourfold $X$ of discriminant 18 birational to a
fibration into sextic del Pezzo surfaces over the projective plane. Notably,
our construction does not rely on the presence of a central simple algebra
representative for $\alpha$. Instead, we prove that a sufficient condition for
such a Brauer class to obstruct the Hasse principle is insolubility of the
fourfold $X$ (and hence the fibers) over $\mathbb{Q}_3$ and local solubility at
all other primes.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Jennifer Berg</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Anthony Várilly-Alvarado</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">22 pages; Magma scripts included as ancillary files in the arXiv
  distribution</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00879v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00879v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00865v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T15:41:46Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T15:41:46Z</published>
    <title>Holomorphic symmetric differentials and a birational characterization of
  Abelian Varieties</title>
    <summary>  A generically generated vector bundle on a smooth projective variety yields a
rational map to a Grassmannian, called Kodaira map. We answer a previous
question, raised by the asymptotic behaviour of such maps, giving rise to a
birational characterization of abelian varieties.
  In particular we prove that, under the conjectures of the Minimal Model
Program, a smooth projective variety is birational to an abelian variety if and
only if it has Kodaira dimension 0 and some symmetric power of its cotangent
sheaf is generically generated by its global sections.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Ernesto C. Mistretta</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00865v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00865v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.01816v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T14:44:14Z</updated>
    <published>2018-05-04T15:04:58Z</published>
    <title>Polynomials and tensors of bounded strength</title>
    <summary>  Notions of rank abound in the literature on tensor decomposition. We prove
that strength, recently introduced for homogeneous polynomials by
Ananyan-Hochster in their proof of Stillman's conjecture and generalised here
to other tensors, is universal among these ranks in the following sense: any
non-trivial Zariski-closed condition on tensors that is functorial in the
underlying vector space implies bounded strength. This generalises a theorem by
Derksen-Eggermont-Snowden on cubic polynomials, as well as a theorem by
Kazhdan-Ziegler which says that a polynomial all of whose directional
derivatives have bounded strength must itself have bounded strength.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Arthur Bik</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jan Draisma</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Rob H. Eggermont</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Improved the bounds on strength as a function of the dimension of the
  space where one first sees nontrivial equations for the tensor property X</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1805.01816v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.01816v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00799v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T13:21:24Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T13:21:24Z</published>
    <title>A family of GL(r) multiplicative Higgs bundles on rational base</title>
    <summary>  In this paper we study a restricted family of holomorphic symplectic leaves
in the Poisson-Lie group $GL_r(\mathcal{K}_{\mathbb{P}^1_x})$ with rational
quadratic Sklyanin brackets induced by a one-form with a single quadratic pole
at $\infty \in \mathbb{P}_{1}$. The restriction of the family is that the
matrix elements in the defining representation are linear functions of $x$. We
study how the symplectic leaves in this family are obtained by the fusion of
certain fundamental symplectic leaves. These symplectic leaves arise as minimal
examples of (i) moduli spaces of multiplicative Higgs bundles on
$\mathbb{P}^{1}$ with prescribed singularities, (ii) moduli spaces of $U(r)$
monopoles on $\mathbb{R}^2 \times S^1$ with Dirac singularities, (iii) Coulomb
branches of the moduli space of vacua of 4d $\mathcal{N}=2$ supersymmetric
$A_{r-1}$ quiver gauge theories compactified on a circle. While degree 1
symplectic leaves regular at $\infty \in \mathbb{P}^1$ (Coulomb branches of the
superconformal quiver gauge theories) are isomorphic to co-adjoint orbits in
$\mathfrak{gl}_{r}$ and their Darboux parametrization and quantization is well
known, the case irregular at infinity (asymptotically free quiver gauge
theories) is novel. We also explicitly quantize the algebra of functions on
these moduli spaces by presenting the corresponding solutions to the quantum
Yang-Baxter equation valued in Heisenberg algebra (free field realization).
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Rouven Frassek</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Vasily Pestun</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">42 pages</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00799v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00799v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="hep-th" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00780v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T12:38:14Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T12:38:14Z</published>
    <title>Existence theorems for abelian integrals and pluriharmonic functions</title>
    <summary>  In this paper, we study closed meromorphic $1$-forms with prescribed residue
divisors. Let $X$ be a compact smooth projective manifold and $W$ be an ample,
normal crossing divisor of $X$. We prove that there is a closed meromorphic
$1$-form on $X$ with singularities on $W$ taking residue divisor $D$ if only if
the generalized first Chern class of $D$ is zero. This is a higher dimensional
generalization of the existence theorem of abelian differentials of the third
kind on Riemann surfaces. As an application, we classify the pluriharmonic
functions on $X$ with singularities on $W$ taking the local form of $f+\bar
h+\sum_{i=1}^la_i\log|z_i|^2$, where $f$ is a meromorphic function, $\bar h$ is
an anti-meromorphic function and $a_i$ is a complex number for $i=1,\cdots,l.$
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hanlong Fang</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00780v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00780v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.CV" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00717v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T09:07:44Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-02T09:07:44Z</published>
    <title>On the B-Semiampleness Conjecture</title>
    <summary>  The B-Semiampleness Conjecture of Prokhorov and Shokurov predicts that the
moduli part in a canonical bundle formula is semiample on a birational
modification. We prove that the restriction of the moduli part to any
sufficiently high divisorial valuation is semiample, assuming the conjecture in
lower dimensions.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Enrica Floris</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Vladimir Lazić</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.01898v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-02T06:41:11Z</updated>
    <published>2018-04-05T15:10:31Z</published>
    <title>Effective divisors on Hurwitz spaces and moduli of curves</title>
    <summary>  We discuss the transition from uniruledness to being of general type for
moduli spaces of curves and Hurwitz spaces of covers. First, we construct and
calculate the class of a virtual divisor on the moduli space of curves of genus
23, having slope less than that of the canonical divisor. Coupled with the
recent solution of the Strong Maximal Rank Conjecture due to Jansen, Payne and
independently to Liu, Osserman, Teixidor and Zhang, it follows that M_{23} a
variety of general type. Secondly, we prove the effectiveness of the canonical
bundle of several Hurwitz spaces of degree k covers of the projective line from
curves of genus 13&lt;g&lt;20.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Gavril Farkas</name>
    </author>

    <title>Galois descent for higher Brauer groups</title>
    <summary>  For $X$ a smooth projective variety over a field $k$, we consider the problem
of Galois descent for higher Brauer groups. More precisely, we extend a
finiteness result of Colliot-Th\'el\`ene and Skorobogatov to higher Brauer
groups.

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.00297v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T19:54:57Z</updated>
    <published>2016-05-01T19:47:50Z</published>
    <title>Irreducibility and components rigid in moduli of the Hilbert scheme of
  smooth curves</title>
    <summary>  Denote by $\mathcal{H}_{d,g,r}$ the Hilbert scheme of smooth curves, that is
the union of components whose general point corresponds to a smooth irreducible
and non-degenerate curve of degree $d$ and genus $g$ in $\mathbb P^r$. A
component of $\mathcal{H}_{d,g,r}$ is rigid in moduli if its image under the
natural map $\pi:\mathcal{H}_{d,g,r} \dashrightarrow \mathcal{M}_{g}$ is a one
point set. In this note, we provide a proof of the fact that
$\mathcal{H}_{d,g,r}$ has no components rigid in moduli for $g &gt; 0$ and $r=3$,
from which it follows that the only smooth projective curves embedded in
$\mathbb P^3$ whose only deformations are given by projective transformations
are the twisted cubic curves. In case $r \geq 4$, we also prove the
non-existence of a component of $\mathcal{H}_{d,g,r}$ rigid in moduli in a
certain restricted range of $d$, $g&gt;0$ and $r$. In the course of the proofs, we
establish the irreducibility of $\mathcal{H}_{d,g,3}$ beyond the range which
has been known before.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Changho Keem</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Yun-Hwan Kim</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Angelo Felice Lopez</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">v2: added (ii) in Cor. 3.6; v3: minor typos corrected</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1605.00297v3" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.00297v3" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00477v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T18:00:26Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T18:00:26Z</published>
    <title>Limits of canonical forms on towers of Riemann surfaces</title>
    <summary>  We prove a generalized version of Kazhdan's theorem for canonical forms on
Riemann surfaces. In the classical version, one starts with an ascending
sequence $\{S_n \rightarrow S\}$ of finite Galois covers of a hyperbolic
Riemann Surface $S$, converging to the universal cover. The theorem states that
the sequence of forms on $S$ inherited from the canonical forms on $S_n$'s
converges uniformly to (a multiple of) the hyperbolic form. We prove a
generalized version of this theorem, where the universal cover is replaced with
any infinite Galois cover. Along the way, we also prove a Gauss--Bonnet type
theorem in the context of arbitrary infinite Galois covers.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Hyungryul Baik</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Farbod Shokrieh</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Chenxi Wu</name>
    </author>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00477v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00477v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.CV" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.DG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="14H55, 14H30, 28A33, 58A10" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1802.00078v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T17:47:02Z</updated>
    <published>2018-01-31T21:44:50Z</published>
    <title>Mayer-Vietoris sequences and equivariant K-theory rings of toric
  varieties</title>
    <summary>  We apply a Mayer-Vietoris sequence argument to identify the Atiyah-Segal
equivariant complex K-theory rings of certain toric varieties with rings of
integral piecewise Laurent polynomials on the associated fans. We provide
necessary and sufficient conditions for this identification to hold for toric
varieties of complex dimension 2, including smooth and singular cases. We prove
that it always holds for smooth toric varieties, regardless of whether or not
the fan is polytopal or complete. Finally, we introduce the notion of fans with
"distant singular cones," and prove that the identification holds for them. The
identification has already been made by Hararda, Holm, Ray and Williams in the
case of divisive weighted projective spaces, in addition to enlarging the class
of toric varieties for which the identification holds, this work provides an
example in which the identification fails. We make every effort to ensure that
our work is rich in examples.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Tara S. Holm</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Gareth Williams</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">22 pages, 3 figures, two appendices. For v2, we have added additional

  area. For v3, we have added yet more details to the introduction, including
  key examples; we have also made additional minor corrections and improvements</arxiv:comment>

    <title>On Generalised Abundance, I</title>
    <summary>  The goal of this paper is to make a surprising connection between several
central conjectures in algebraic geometry: the Nonvanishing Conjecture, the
Abundance Conjecture, and the Semiampleness Conjecture for nef line bundles on
K-trivial varieties.
</summary>

    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.07103v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T17:15:43Z</updated>
    <published>2018-03-19T18:24:36Z</published>
    <title>Divisors on matroids and their volumes</title>
    <summary>  The classical volume polynomial in algebraic geometry measures the degrees of
ample (and nef) divisors on a smooth projective variety. We introduce an
analogous volume polynomial for matroids, and give a complete combinatorial
formula. For a realizable matroid, we thus obtain an explicit formula for the
classical volume polynomial of the associated wonderful compactification. We
then introduce a new invariant called the volume of a matroid as a particular
specialization of its volume polynomial, and discuss its algebro-geometric and
combinatorial properties in connection to graded linear series on blow-ups of
projective spaces.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Christopher Eur</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">21 pages, 3 figures. An update: resolved two questions in the

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.01536v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T15:59:01Z</updated>

    <title>Quantum Langlands duality of representations of W-algebras</title>
    <summary>  We prove duality isomorphisms of certain representations of W-algebras which
play an essential role in the quantum geometric Langlands Program and some
related results.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Tomoyuki Arakawa</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Edward Frenkel</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">28 pages</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.09038v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T15:37:18Z</updated>
    <published>2018-07-24T11:18:19Z</published>
    <title>Coulomb branches of 3-dimensional gauge theories and related structures</title>
    <summary>  These are (somewhat informal) lectures notes for the CIME summer school
"Geometric Representation Theory and Gauge Theory" in June 2018. In these notes
we review the results and constructions of a series of our joint papers with
H.Nakajima where a mathematical definition of Coulomb branches of 3d N=4
quantum gauge theories (of cotangent type) is given. We also discuss some
further constructions (such as categories of line operators in the
corresponding topologically twisted theories) and briefly discuss a connection
to local geometric Langlands correspondence.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Alexander Braverman</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Michael Finkelberg</name>
    </author>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00378v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T15:36:38Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T15:36:38Z</published>
    <title>From singularities to graphs</title>
    <summary>  In this paper I analyze the problems which led to the introduction of graphs
as tools for studying surface singularities. I explain how such graphs were
initially only described using words, but that several questions made it
necessary to draw them, leading to the elaboration of a special calculus with
graphs. This is a non-technical paper intended to be readable both by
mathematicians and philosophers or historians of mathematics.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Patrick Popescu-Pampu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">23 pages, 27 figures. Expanded version of the talk given at the

  at Lyc\'ee Henri IV in Paris from 25 to 27 January 2018</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00339v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T14:30:58Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T14:30:58Z</published>
    <title>On triangle equivalences of stable categories</title>
    <summary>  We apply the Auslander-Buchweitz approximation theory to show that the Iyama
and Yoshino's subfactor triangulated category can be realized as a triangulated
quotient. Applications of this realization go in three directions. Firstly, we
recover both a result of Iyama and Yang and a result of the third author.
Secondly, we extend the classical Buchweitz's triangle equivalence from
Iwanaga-Gorenstein rings to Noetherian rings. Finally, we obtain the converse
of Buchweitz's triangle equivalence and a result of Beligiannis, and give
characterizations for Iwanaga-Gorenstein rings and Gorenstein algebras
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Zhenxing Di</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Zhongkui Liu</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Jiaqun Wei</name>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00335v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T14:24:29Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T14:24:29Z</published>
    <title>Linear compartmental models: input-output equations and operations that
  preserve identifiability</title>
    <summary>  This work focuses on the question of how identifiability of a mathematical
model, that is, whether parameters can be recovered from data, is related to
identifiability of its submodels. We look specifically at linear compartmental
models and investigate when identifiability is preserved after adding or
removing model components. In particular, we examine whether identifiability is
preserved when an input, output, edge, or leak is added or deleted. Our
approach, via differential algebra, is to analyze specific input-output
equations of a model and the Jacobian of the associated coefficient map. We
clarify a prior determinantal formula for these equations, and then use it to
prove that, under some hypotheses, a model's input-output equations can be
understood in terms of certain submodels we call "output-reachable". Our proofs
use algebraic and combinatorial techniques.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Elizabeth Gross</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Heather A. Harrington</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Nicolette Meshkat</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Anne Shiu</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">22 pages, 3 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00335v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.00335v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00311v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T13:22:48Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T13:22:48Z</published>
    <title>Four dimensional Fano quiver flag zero loci (with an appendix by T.
  Coates, E. Kalashnikov, and A. Kasprzyk)</title>
    <summary>  Quiver flag zero loci are subvarieties of quiver flag varieties cut out by
sections of homogeneous vector bundles. We prove the Abelian non-Abelian
Correspondence in this context: this allows us to compute genus zero
Gromov--Witten invariants of quiver flag zero loci. We determine the ample cone
of a quiver flag variety, disproving a conjecture of Craw. In the Appendix,
which is joint work with Tom Coates and Alexander Kasprzyk, we use these
results to find four dimensional Fano manifolds that occur as quiver flag zero
loci in ambient spaces of dimension up to 8, and compute their quantum periods.
In this way we find at least 139 new four dimensional Fano manifolds.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Elana Kalashnikov</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">16 pages with a 40 page appendix, including results of computer
  algebra calculations</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00304v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T12:55:48Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T12:55:48Z</published>
    <title>Picard group and fundamental group of the moduli of Higgs bundles on
  curves</title>
    <summary>  Let $X$ be an irreducible smooth projective curve of genus $g \geq 2$ over
$\mathbb{C}$. Let $G$ be a connected reductive affine algebraic group over
$\mathbb{C}$. Let $\mathrm{M}_{G, {\rm Higgs}}^{\delta}$ be the moduli space of
semistable principal $G$--Higgs bundles on $X$ of topological type $\delta \in
\pi_1(G)$. In this article, we compute the fundamental group and Picard group
of $\mathrm{M}_{G, {\rm Higgs}}^{\delta}$.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Sujoy Chakraborty</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Arjun Paul</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:doi xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">10.1515/coma-2018-0009</arxiv:doi>
    <link title="doi" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1515/coma-2018-0009" rel="related"/>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">Final Version</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.02749v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T12:51:51Z</updated>
    <published>2018-01-09T01:58:08Z</published>
    <title>Degenerations and Lagrangian fibrations of Calabi-Yau manifolds</title>
    <summary>  We discuss various topics on degenerations and special Lagrangian torus
fibrations of Calabi-Yau manifolds in the context of mirror symmetry. A
particular emphasis is on Tyurin degenerations and the Doran-Harder-Thompson
conjecture, which builds a bridge between mirror symmetry for Calabi-Yau
manifolds and that for quasi-Fano manifolds. The proof of the conjecture is of
interest in its own right and leads us to a few other related topics such as
SYZ mirror symmetry, theta functions and geometric quantization. Inspired by
the conjecture, we also propose a new construction of Landau-Ginzburg models by
splitting Calabi-Yau fibrations.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Atsushi Kanazawa</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">fixed some typos, changed the title, 55 pages, 8 figures, Handbook

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00280v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T11:44:21Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T11:44:21Z</published>
    <title>Local acyclicity in $p$-adic cohomology</title>
    <summary>  We prove an analogue for $p$-adic coefficients of the Deligne--Laumon theorem
on local acyclicity for curves. That is, for an overconvergent $F$-isocrystal
$E$ on a relative curve $f:U\rightarrow S$ admitting a good compactification,
we show that the cohomology sheaves of $\mathbf{R}f_!E$ are overconvergent
isocrystals if and only if $E$ has constant Swan conductor at infinity.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Christopher Lazda</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">45 pages, comments welcome</arxiv:comment>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1712.09737v3</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T11:23:46Z</updated>
    <published>2017-12-26T18:53:04Z</published>
    <title>Complete sets of logarithmic vector fields for integration-by-parts
  identities of Feynman integrals</title>
    <summary>  Integration-by-parts identities between loop integrals arise from the
vanishing integration of total derivatives in dimensional regularization.
Generic choices of total derivatives in the Baikov or parametric
representations lead to identities which involve dimension shifts. These
dimension shifts can be avoided by imposing a certain constraint on the total
derivatives. The solutions of this constraint turn out to be a specific type of
syzygies which correspond to logarithmic vector fields along the Gram
determinant formed of the independent external and loop momenta. We present an
explicit generating set of solutions in Baikov representation, valid for any
number of loops and external momenta, obtained from the Laplace expansion of
the Gram determinant. We provide a rigorous mathematical proof that this set of
solutions is complete. This proof relates the logarithmic vector fields in
question to ideals of submaximal minors of the Gram matrix and makes use of
classical resolutions of such ideals.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Janko Boehm</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Alessandro Georgoudis</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Kasper J. Larsen</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Mathias Schulze</name>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Yang Zhang</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:doi xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">10.1103/PhysRevD.98.025023</arxiv:doi>
    <link title="doi" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevD.98.025023" rel="related"/>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">12 pages, two-column format, 3 figures. Added example with internal

    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00231v1</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T08:51:23Z</updated>
    <published>2018-08-01T08:51:23Z</published>
    <title>On the first steps of the minimal model program for the moduli space of
  stable pointed curves</title>
    <summary>  The aim of this paper is to study all the natural first steps of the minimal
model program for the moduli space of stable pointed curves. We prove that they
admit a modular interpretation and we study their geometric properties. As a
particular case, we recover the first few Hassett-Keel log canonical models. As
a by-product, we produce many birational morphisms from the moduli space of
stable pointed curves to alternative modular projective compactifications of
the moduli space of pointed curves.
</summary>
    <author>

    <title>On the algebraic boundaries among typical ranks for real binary forms</title>
    <summary>  We describe the algebraic boundaries of the regions of real binary forms with
fixed typical rank and of degree at most eight, showing that they are dual
varieties of suitable coincident root loci.

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.02699v2</id>
    <updated>2018-08-01T03:52:15Z</updated>
    <published>2016-02-08T19:14:53Z</published>
    <title>A family of projectively natural polygon iterations</title>
    <summary>  The pentagram map was invented by Richard Schwartz in his search for a
projective-geometric analogue of the midpoint map. It turns out that the
dynamical behavior of the pentagram map is totally different from that of the
midpoint map. Recently, Schwartz has constructed a related map, the projective
heat map, which empirically exhibits similar dynamics as the midpoint map. In
this paper, we will demonstrate that there is a one-parameter family of maps
which behaves a lot like Schwartz's projective heat map.
</summary>
    <author>
      <name>Quang-Nhat Le</name>
    </author>
    <arxiv:comment xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom">24 pages, 10 figures</arxiv:comment>
    <link href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.02699v2" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link title="pdf" href="http://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.02699v2" rel="related" type="application/pdf"/>
    <arxiv:primary_category xmlns:arxiv="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom" term="math.DS" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.DS" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="math.AG" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
